Box Gridder

class data_processing.box_gridder.BoxGridder(data=None, grid_size=None, output_path=None, independent_variables=['x', 'y', 'z'], dependent_variable='C', input_data_logarithmised=False, output_data_logarithmised=False, processed_data=None)

Bases: object

Class to create a 3D grid enclosing 3D spatial data. The class averages the data points in each grid box. The grid box centroids are set as the location of each averaged value. The class can visualise either averages, or data points count, in each box. The class can generate histograms for a random sample of grid boxes.

Arguments:

  • data: DataFrame containing the 3D spatial data.

  • grid_size: List containing the grid size in each dimension.

  • output_path: String, path to the data directory.

  • independent_variables: String List of independent variable names.

  • dependent_variable: String, the dependent variable name.

  • input_data_logarithmised: Boolean, indicating logarithmised data.

  • output_data_logarithmised: Boolean, flag output logarithmisation.

  • processed_data: DataFrame containing the already averaged data.

Attributes:

  • data: DataFrame containing the 3D spatial data.

  • grid_size: List containing the grid size in each dimension.

  • output_path: String, path to the data directory.

  • independent_variables: String List of independent variable names.

  • dependent_variable: String, the dependent variable name.

  • input_data_logarithmised: Boolean, indicating logarithmised data.

  • output_data_logarithmised: Boolean, flag output logarithmisation.

  • processed_data: DataFrame containing the averaged data.

  • samples: List of tuples, containing the samples within each box.

get_sample_histograms(n_hists=5)

Generate histograms for a random sample of grid squares. Histograms are saved in the output directory.

Return type:

None

Arguments:

  • n_hists: Integer, number of histograms to generate.

visualise_counts()

Visualise a 3D grid of averaged data. Visualises either averages, or data points count, in each box. The plot is saved in the output directory.

Return type:

None

Arguments:
  • type: String, either ‘value’ or ‘counts’ depending on the desired

    visualisation.
